metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. Sree Rama Talkies (assessee-company)

facts.text: The assessee-company is a private limited company owning a cinema house called Sree Rama Talkies at Bobbili, taxed on profits from exhibition of films.

At Board of Directors meeting on September 9, 1955, resolved to authorise Managing Director (Raja of Bobbili) to negotiate with Zamindar of Chikkavaram or nominee for sale of entire concern with equipment, machinery, fittings etc. for Rs. 1,20,000/-
Agreement concluded for sale, confirmed by assessee-company at extra-ordinary general body meeting on October 4, 1955.

Deed called 'exchange deed' executed on February 21, 1956; assessee transferred cinema house, buildings, movables, goodwill etc. (Schedule I) for 5 tax-free cumulative preference shares in Sri Rama Sugar and Industries Ltd., Bobbili (face value Rs. 1,20,000/-, Schedule II) held by Zamindar and Zamindarini of Chikkavaram.
Separate valuation: immovable property Rs. 60,000/-, movables etc. and goodwill Rs. 60,000/- each.
Possession of property handed over on September 9, 1955.
For assessment year 1956-57, assessee submitted return showing Rs. 9,823/- as profits from transaction.
Income-tax Officer found value realised exceeded written down value (WDV) by Rs. 43,568/-, computed profits under S. 10(2)(vii) Income-tax Act, 1922, included in taxable income.
ITO order confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, except allowing Rs. 5,000/- for cost of goodwill.
As directed by High Court, Tribunal stated case under S. 66(2) Income-tax Act, 1922 in Referred No. 6 of 1963.
Andhra Pradesh High Court judgment dated October 30, 1964 answered reference in favour of assessee-company against Commissioner.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transaction dated 21-2-1956 amounts to a sale within the purview of the second proviso to section 10(2)(vii) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
Whether the consideration for the sale is not the market value of the shares as on the date of the transaction, namely, Rs. 95/- per share, but the face value of the shares.

petitioner_arguments.text: The transaction was a sale for money consideration of Rs. 1,20,000/-, mode of payment by transfer of shares; resolutions referred to 'sale' and fixed consideration at Rs. 1,20,000/-
In revenue matters, substance over form: in substance a sale for Rs. 1,20,000/- though paid by shares.

respondent_arguments.text: Transaction is an exchange, not a sale, as consideration was shares, not money.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S. 54 Transfer of Property Act; S. 2(10), S. 4 Sale of Goods Act; S. 118 Transfer of Property Act

court_reasoning.text: Words 'sale' or 'sold' not defined in Income-tax Act, 1922; construed via S. 54 Transfer of Property Act (sale is transfer for price/money) and Sale of Goods Act S. 2(10) (price as money consideration); exchange under S. 118 Transfer of Property Act is mutual transfer neither/wholly money.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presence of money consideration essential for sale; here consideration was shares, so exchange/barter, not sale.

court_reasoning.text: Document titled 'exchange deed'; preamble and operative part describe exchange of properties in Schedules I and II; no money price paid/promised.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Recitals/resolutions do not control operative part; valuation for stamp duty only.

court_reasoning.text: No bad faith/fraud alleged; tax per legal effect of document, not disregarding form for substance (citing Bank of Chettinad, Duke of Westminster).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctrine of substance over form erroneous in revenue without fraud; apply letter of law to legal rights.

holdings.text: Transaction dated February 21, 1956 is an exchange, not a sale; Income-tax authorities not entitled to treat as sale and apply S. 10(2)(vii) Income-tax Act, 1922.

precedents_cited.relevance: Price in S. 54 TPA same sense as S. 4 Sale of Goods Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bank of Chettinad Ltd. v. C.I.T. Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Doctrine of substance over form erroneous in revenue cases; tax per letter of law.
Cannot disregard legal rights/liabilities under contract for tax; ordinary construction applies.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State in Council of India v. Scoble
precedents_cited.relevance: Ascertain legal rights, disregard mere nomenclature.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Wesleyan and General Assurance Society
precedents_cited.relevance: Real character of transaction matters, not parties' name; but per legal rights.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Profits on sale of assets exceeding WDV deemed income; reference to HC.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines sale (transfer for price/money); exchange (mutual transfer not wholly money).

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: Price means money consideration; contract of sale transfers property for price.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave filed by Commissioner of Income-tax against Andhra Pradesh High Court judgment favouring assessee; held transaction was exchange, not sale, no tax under S. 10(2)(vii).
outcome.relief_granted: In favour of assessee-company; no inclusion of Rs. 43,568/- as profits.

key_quotes.text: "Sale is a transfer of ownership in exchange for a price paid or promised or part-paid and part-promised."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Definition from S. 54 TPA central to distinguishing sale from exchange.

key_quotes.text: "The presence of money consideration is therefore an essential element in a transaction of sale. If the consideration is not money but some other valuable consideration it may be an exchange or barter but not a sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key reasoning why transaction not taxable under S. 10(2)(vii).

key_quotes.text: "In the absence of any suggestion of bad faith or fraud the true principle is that the taxing statute has to be applied in accordance with the legal rights of the parties to the transaction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects substance over form argument without fraud.

key_quotes.text: "If, on the other hand, the doctrine means that you may brush aside deeds, disregard the legal rights and liabilities arising under a contract between parties... then I entirely dissent from such a doctrine."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Duke of Westminster upholding form/legal effect.
